{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3173341,"name":"Josh","username":"bruingineer","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/b/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-26T19:36:47.372Z","cooked":"

First, some info about our bot. We are running SDS Mk4i swerve modules with falcons and CANcoders, and we have no issues.

We are using two additional CANCoders on other arm joints. Both of these are exhibiting weird behavior. Both show green LEDs, so the magnets are within a good range to the sensor.

From the zero position, after moving the joint until the encoder reads 90 degrees, the measured the real physical angle is closer to 110 degrees. Going the other way until the encoder reads -90 degrees, the physical measured angle is closer to -70 degrees. Moving the encoder back to 0 degrees puts it to the correct physical zero point.

It seems like something is causing positive values to count “slow” and negative values to count “fast”.

Has anyone seen this before?

A theory:
The magnet and sensor are mounted with too much eccentricity. I have not tested this theory yet. An off-season project may be in order. The user manual for the CANCoders states the the eccentricity, as long as it’s close, should not affect the readings too significantly.
